Effects of compost incorporation on soil physical, chemical and biological properties.
Rothamsted workers: Mr. Nat Hughes and Professor Phil Brookes.

Collaborators: Dr Richard Whalley and Mr. Chris Watts, Silsoe Research Institute, Silsoe, Beds. Professor Anna Benneddetti, Dr. Maria Teresa, Del'Abate Instituto Sperimentale per la Nutrizione della Piante di Roma, 00184 Rome, Italy.
Funders: Enviros Ltd, Regus House, 101 Cambridge Business Park, Cambourne, Cambridge CB3 6DP. Phone: +44 (0)870 165 2400

There is now increasing interest in composting of waste from domestic, amenity and industrial sources. While once considered to be uneconomic it is now recognised that landfill brings its own financial and environmental problems and composting is increasing in importance as a means of recycling of wastes and in improving soil structure and soil fertility. This project is funded by ENVIROS and we are investigating the effects of compost incorporation on soil physical, chemical and biological properties.
We are using the site at Loudham Hall. This is a conventionally managed commercial field, currently growing potatoes when we sampled it. Treatments studied are: Nil: Inorganic fertiliser (Fs)
There are 4 replicates per treatment. Analyses include soil organic matter, microbial biomass and respiration and thermal analysis for humic substance characterisation.
